number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Visceral, action filled and full of the satisfying dismemberment of the poor sods who get in the way of of a virtually indomitable superhuman consumed by a biological virus. It's an open world game in the spirit of the classic 'Incredible Hulk Ultimate Destruction' on the original Xbox. Set in the aftermath of the first game, yet again NYC becomes the victim of a biological apocalpyse set off by Alex Mercer dragging in Gentek and Blackwatch. Mercer infects a soldier, Heller, who develops the powers of his protege as he goes on a rampage killing anything and everything from both sides of the conflict in a quest for revenge for his daughter. The free roam mechanics in this game are without question the best out of any game I've played. It is simply satisfying to run at superhuman through the war torn streets of New York, leaping up the sides of skycrapers and cruising along them then jumping and gliding high above the conflict. The sense of weight and power you carry without feeling cumbersome or bulky is just nailed, you look and feel like a lithe, dealdly human predator. Story and side missions along with the usual collectilbes are scattered around the map, which is split into 3 seperate parts. While I lost the sense of a large city I got from the first, it let all the elements of the map have personality, which is a tradeoff I'm willing to take. The weapons and upgrades are disappointedly almost the same as number one with only a few differences. They are all still visually impressive and satisfying, but I held expectations for a more substantial roster of weapon options. The combat and movements mechanics are likewise similar with a familiar set of enemies, with just enough changes to justify its existence as a new game. The Evolved are quite cool though, plus it provides an enemy that plays and operates similar to yourself. The difficulty level is quite easy once you have a few upgrades, the tools at your disposal allow you to ignore or avoid almost all incoming damage sources. My first playthough on hard was very straightforward.Prototype 2 is not the best game ever. I haven't even bothered to review the story, because there's really nothing to say. It's passable if that, but it does its job in giving you a reason to tear though a collapsing city under siege. There isn't the greatest expansion in concepts from the first game, but enough to add some mild spice. Despite this, Prototype 2 is fun. It's simply fun, the core gameplay is nailed down so very well, fun is all a game needs to be.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												Finished (did the last main mission) after 28 hours.These were ca. 23 pure fun, blood, action and carnage.And the last 5 hours PURE frustration. The last mission. This really bad last mission which kills all the fun you had all that time.If you would just play the mission without dying, it would be, don't know 15 minutes.It took me 5 hours to beat the END BOSS. ♥♥♥♥ it!Until then, I had a main stories, some side stories, action without endand the feeling that I am the overpowered king of the city.At least until 3 infected or 4 attack helicopters or worse, all at the same time came at me.Then it would become even more hectic and fun.And sometimes I died... in the beginning.You get more and more powers, but not so many that you get confused.A lot of your upgrades are passive ones or only useable in certain situations, like destroy tank with one attack, or do that attack 75% faster or run x% faster or have more health or have more "hounds" in your pack.All updates are useful somehow, you can take enemy helicopters after a while andjust use them or glide around the city and do attacks from above orignore the main story and have fun.The game did not crash once in these 28 hours.And I do not have a special computer.:Processor	Intel(R) Core(TM)2 Quad CPU    Q9550  @ 2.83GHz, 2832 Mhz, 4 Core(s), 4 Logical Processor(s)Name	NVIDIA GeForce GTX 660 Ti8 GB RAMI was able to run it with max details and no fps problems at all.The game is easier than the first one, which is somehow a nice thing.You had a lot more moving and fighting options in the first one, which was nice too.However, if you want fun and blood, then this is a very good game.If you can beat the last enemy in half an hour, then you are a semi god at least :)Really good game, way too hard last enemy. Buy it anyways!

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Prototype 2 is so utterly ridiculous that it's hard to wipe the smile from your face. It starts out weak but ends SO MUCH, much stronger, although its missions and storyline never really rise to a level beyond “enjoyable.” Even so, it’s enormously fun as an open-world playground, especially once all of Heller’s powers are at your disposal; there are always fun ways to experiment, to cause horrific violence and to watch the hapless pedestrians scatter. If you’re looking for an epic, hugely varied adventure, look elsewhere, but if you want a game that lets you run amok in creative, bloody ways, Prototype 2 is pretty incredible.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												CONI'm not a huge fan of games where they tell you whom to play. That said, that's my main grudge against P2 -- you can't really choose what your character looks like, what his backstory is, etc. etc., and the fact that like in P1, it isn't really anyone too likeable doesn't help.The control scheme now lets you choose two active powers versus Prototype 1's one, and while that sounds nice (especially the option to assign a slow move and a fast move, or a close range one and a long-range / area one), I didn't really find it all that useful in the game (I would assign one fast, close range attack as primary power and use it 95 % of the time, and have something like tendrils -- or later whip fist -- as a secondary for the rare cases where I needed to attack a helicopter or needed an area effect. Using each roughly 50 % for great synergy? Not so much. But maybe, that was just me.).The downside is that while you get twice as many active skills, you have to handle them with the same number of buttons on the controller, and the controls feel less precise than in P1. Ironically, the most annoying issue wasn't even attack related; if you don't get quite the right attack, but still an attack, it's usually non-catastrophic. What I did get often enough for it to be a nuisance however was being on a stealth mission, pressing (B) to interact with some hapless soldier (usually to consume them and gain their memories; sometimes just to stop him keeping an eye on the person you came for), and instead prying lose some feature of the landscape that also happened to be close (but didn't even necessarily look like you could interact with it). And well, prying lose random ACs or oiltanks or whatever automatically raises an alert and ruins the stealth part of your mission. (This can also be an issue during melee, where you get a prompt to press (B) to consume an enemy who's been weakened enough, but who may die soon, and where in crowded locations (B) will then often select bystanders seemingly at random, all while your actual target is bleeding out.I liked the skill system in P1 better (get XP for everything, then once you have enough XP to improve whatever skill you're interested in (i.e. buy many minor things quickly, or save up for big improvements)) vs P2's "you'll level up again at so-and-so many XP, and every time you do, you can improve exactly one skill", but in the end, it wasn't a huge factor.(That said, the thing where you can get a skill buy eating the brain of someone who has it still exists.)PROUnsurprisingly, the city looks much better than in P1; the player character looks much better, the voice acting is decent this time, and most of all, while there are certainly repetitive elements (mostly the Blacknet assassinations, which often don't have much in the way of plot -- this is even lampshaded one time: "So this guy is an APC driver? Doesn't really sound like a big bad mover and shaker ... ah, whatever, I'll kill him anyway."), the game, especially the main quest, feels much more like a story than the first game did at the best of times, and a sense of urgency is upheld at (almost) all times. Like a soap opera or Baking Bread, it isn't necessarily the cleverest plot on earth, but each mission creates enough of a cliffhanger to make you wonder what will happen next, and it's tremendously easy to get sucked into "just one more mission before bed."As a bonus, much of the optional "color" of the setting is now told through audio logs you can find (and listen to while you move along), rather than flickering memories with corny visuals that don't really blend with the rest of the game and that interrupt your flow like in P1. Small change, surprisingly big effect. (Technically I guess they're a cross between the landmark orbs and the "color" memories of P1, but I played P1 and P2 in the same week, so it's becoming a bit of a blur.)There are challenges and mini-games and somewhat repetitive kill zones, but unlike in Saints Row IV, they're not mandatory -- you can do one once in a while for variety or XP, or do them after the main quest for something to do with your then near maxed-out powers. Or, you can ignore them completely, and just do the main quest. Your choice.The gliding, especially once upgraded, still won't carry you as far as SR IV's, but it feels world's away from P1's, which never felt much better than plain old falling.A big plus: Starting maybe 2/3 in, P1 would just try to overwhelm you -- gliding was practically useless, perhaps in an attempt to keep you at street level, and at street level, there'd be a constant barrage -- even if for once, zombies weren't attacking you and soldiers weren't detecting you, you'd frequently ragdoll all over the place simply for getting caught in random crossfire of the marines or blackwatch using tanks and rockets at street level. Yes, it sounds good on paper -- getting swarmed is obviously very much a zombie trope, and the careless use of artillery demonstrated desperation / casual disregard for any survivors, but in reality, it just makes for a really unfun game mechanic when the true challenge of a misison isn't Doing The Thing, but getting there to do the thing. Meh. (This was exacerbated by the fact that using any speed powers could get a strike team called on you.)  In P2, you get caught in the cross fire much less easily, you don't get swarmed by the zombies as much, strike teams aren't called in as easily, take longer to arrive, are easier to shake off, and are easier to kill. Heck, it's almost too easy in P2, but I'll take that over P1's traversing the city being a chore any day. P2 has "joy of movement!" :)RECOMMENDATIONIf you can stomach playing a character that they picked, rather than one that you picked, give it a go, especially if you've played part one, but get it while it's on sale. (It seems pretty much too late to vote with your dollar anyway, now that they've already downsized Radical -- which is actually a shame, I would've been interested in seeing how a Prototype 3 would've come out.)

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												I enjoyed this game more than I thought I would.  However I did have that glitch early in the game that required me to set my CPU to one core in order to move on in the story, but quickly changed it back to all 4 cores.The 10 hour single player game is worth the price if you like Third Person open world action games.  The game ran smooth with 50+ monsters, helicopters, tanks, soldiers, and stuff flying everywhere.  Running around, flying, and parkour all was smooth/fun.You can pick up guns, do side quests to beef up your char, or just cause massive damage to an area.  It has a bit of stealth as well, but mostly not required.  The story is just your typical - Rough tough good guy smashing bad guys and getting tricked along the way, but every hour or so you get a new method of attacking and killing so I kept rolling forward.If you want a GTA Meets Superman, but with Zombies/Monsters/Big Cities then this is the game for you.  Just don't expect anything more than a fun smash and bash action game.Would play again if I didn't have so many other games to play.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2013
												Another great Prototype game from Radical Entertainment/Activision. In fact, many people have negative views on this game, probably because of some repetitive missions and the fact that Alex Mercer is not really depicted as a good guy in general. But many of bad reviews seem to come from those people who do not know how to play games like this.Now, I am not sure if I can just boldly say that Prototype 2 is any inferior to the prequel. In my honest opinion, Prototype 2 was just as good, if not better. There are many missions that make you infiltrate the facilities and consume people and such (Actually, pretty much most of missions are like that) and I guess people might find this rather boring. But in my opinion, I liked the fact that the game was focusing more on the story, rather than action in general. This, does not mean the game is boring at all.As for the action part, well, the game is certainly easier than the first Prototype. When the first one makes you get real busy with your controller (or keyboard and mouse), I didn't think the second one was like that in general. But this doesn't mean you can just sit back and relax, you still better buckle down, especially the final boss fight. I kind of do not like how the upgrade system changed in this game....I wish I could just buy whatever the upgrade I want to buy if I can afford like I could in the first one. But well, I wouldn't say this is a deal-breaker. Overall, fun game. Even though I can not really approve the ending and all, as an action game, it is one heck of a ride. 9.8/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3
												Prototype 2 takes the concept of its predecessor and basically improves every bit.Traversal of the city is far less of a mega speeded cluster♥♥♥♥ than in the first game. Explosives and combos can now finally be countered, combat is more varied and fun, and the missions and story are more coherent. Also gone is the stupid web of intrigue which was just a pointless system of wasting time. Now instead you can hunt certain VIPs, which is a much more satisfying experience. Side missions and collectibles give you access to new mutations, which make your character stronger and with enough experience the protagonist can level up and improve speed, health and other stats in meaningful and also at times interesting ways.This is easily one of the better and more gruesome open world games out there. The only caveat at least on Windows 10 is that in fullscreen mode in native resolution you are apparently not able to alt tab. That's more of a windows issue though I'd say. The other GAME BREAKING bug in the game occurs very early on in the 3rd mission or so. This mission will simply not progress, unless you can alt tab out of the game (set the resolution to lower as native if it isn't working), open the task manager and allocate only 1 core to the game. There are multiple threads online so you should be fine. That's also the only time this bug occurs. How the processors and the mission not triggering are connected, is beyond me though...Enjoy your time with this fun open world brawler focussed on total destruction.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2012
												Let's get straight to the point: Prototype 2 is the better game compared to its predecessor. It's practically the same game, with a different main character, some RPG elements, and improved graphics. Now, it does run poorer. As in; the framerate is unstable. Where Prototype 1 gave you a solid 60FPS, P2 gives us anything ranging from 30 to 60+. It's definitely playable, but it's not the smoothest experience. There are a lot of sidemissions, many of them better and with more variation and the carnage remains the same, which is excellent and fast. By completing certain objectives (consuming people, destroying lairs, etc) you'll gain XP points. With every level you gain you'll unlock a power in a certain category. This depends on the mission/objective you completed. It works really well. And where the first game had way too many moves, this one has just enough and they're easy to pull off as well. Another improvement is the fact that stealth consuming is made more easier. Fun fun fun ![Rating: 92/100]

Posted: May 22, 2015
												I'll have to admit that I never played the first PROTOTYPE even though I own it since I found the controls to be horrible. Luckily, it's been fixed in this successor. Controls are okay in this game. You will jump in the wrong direction every now and then but it's not too annoying. Graphics as well as sound are at least decent. And now the most important part: Gameplay.The devs did a great job here in my opinion. The missions are motivating and fun. Sadly, they are a bit repetitive as well. A good thing as well is the fact that you are being rewarded for doing the whole collectible stuff. This should be mandatory in every game including those. tl;dr: A great Open World game. If you don't feel like playing games like Saint's Row or GTAV, you may definitely grab this title in a sale since it's great fun for a couple of hours.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												As others have put it elsewhere, you basically get to be Carnage in a various-states-of-mayhem New York City (known as New York Zero following the events of the first game). Heller isn't "homicidal madman" like Carnage, though, but it's still super fun to play with the mutation powers. If you've played the first, you'll basically ease right in to the second - it's honestly been years since I played the original, but I felt more or less right at home (after a little bit of keybind switching, it's basically just as I remember it). Mechanically, bases are only infiltrated within the context of missions (story and side), and lairs are one-and-done deals, unlike in the first game where both enemy building types could manifest at predetermined sites throughout the world. The Web of Intrigue is done away with, but you still consume named individuals and view their memories. This time around, though, individuals are tied to //BLACKWATCH missions most of the time, and you get an ability to hunt down these individuals (versus mostly running around the city and praying for the target to spawn), making things FAR less of a hassle in that department.As I recall, Musclemass isn't a thing in this installment as it was in the first one, but you do get the Tendril power which is plenty of fun on its own (though it kind of makes me think of using Lanky Kong's melee attacks in DK64). Every other power feels very satisfying to use and pretty viable the entire game through.Overall, pretty good when on sale - turn your brain off, though, because it's not necessarily top-notch in terms of writing, character development, or voice acting. But then again, that can make it feel like a cheesy horror-ish actiony B-movie, so that can work in its favour. It's worth a few afternoons of play.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												New York has been devastated by hideous mutative virus and the only hope for at least a somewhat happy outcome is a soldier wracked with PTSD, visions of his lost family and on a quest for vengeance… Oh and he is literally an indestructible super mutant. Sound fun? Then you should get this game.Now where to start, this game is more fun than a barrel full of radioactive plague monkeys hopped up on Vicodin. This game takes place a few years after the events of the first title, knowledge of which is not needed as you get a history lesson almost immediately before getting infected with the super virus that turns you into a freaking super hero… of death I guess.The game offers you three large open worlds to explore, each representing a portion of New York city and each very different in their own way. If you’ve seen NY then you will know your way around. Yellow zone is a huge slum where the oppressive totalitarian Government crushes all under boot, the green zone is… well much the same as NY now but the red zone, that’s where it’s at. Huge packs of rabid mutants roam the streets, the buildings toppled and destroyed. I loved that place.The combat is one of the best parts of this or any other game. As mentioned you are a super hero, sorta. You can fly, jump over skyscrapers rip people in half, hurl tanks into other tanks and all that cool stuff. Not only that but you come with more blades than a Swiss army knife and each one of deadly powers is so much fun to use. My fav was infection citizens and turning them into living goop bombs before lobbing them at passers-by and watching the carnage. This game makes you feel like a bad a.s.s, the most bad a.s.sed bad a.s.s that ever roamed the streets of NYC. With your array of powers you could destroy entire armies or mutants and humans alike. Slicing, dicing and smashing them to bits before transforming into someone else and walking away as if nothing’s happened. This game gives you the power to be anyone; You just have to consume them. That’s right, your powers health and abilities rely on how many people you can eat using your tentacles. All of the things you can possibly imagine are given to you via a large tech tree and levelling system.Not only can you use your bare hands to deal a lot of damage there are also vehicles in this game too. Tanks, helicopters and..… Well not many different vehicles but each one can blow the heck out of anything infront of it. You can also utilize your enemies weapons, slicing someone apart and then blowing up his friends with his grenade launcher, classic.The story is great too, a man’s tale of vengeance, betrayal and hope lead him to save the world from a psychopath hell bent on forcing humanities evolution. Also there is a government conspiracy in there somewhere. The characters are great and I felt really connected to the protagonist, just like everyone else he absorbs. The music was good, not great but it served its purpose. There are a ton of collectables that offer a nice amount of back story and hidden information and I had a good time tracking them all down.This game is awesome; there is a lot of enjoyment to be had. It is not overly long even though its open world but what’s there will entertain you for hours. Plus if you are anything like me the pure gory death you inflict on others is enough to get me hooked. Buy this allday anyday and you will not be diapointed.Have Fun ^_^

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												I missed out on the first prototype, but had this the last time it was on sale with steam.  It played wonderfully on my slightly older pc, nice graphics and i found the storyline to be imersive and fun, if a bit gory, to play.  Mutate yourself into whatever type of hero, or villan, you want to be!What I could not get my head around are the number of glitches in the game, these according to the forums have caused numerous buyers stress, the breaking point came when i reached a point in the game where i could no longer progress in the storyline as a glitch simply stopped the next mission from loading.  I'm about a third of the way into the game, and all i can do now is rampage around the map killing zombies, soldiers, or innocent civilians who get in my way.  I'm completely stuck, and there seems no way around the problem.Uninstalling and reinstalling, wiping the temporary files, wiping all the saves and starting from scratch, nothing works as it seems for me the game is simply broken.Steam should be ashamed to put this back on sale, without first adding a refund button you can use when it simply breaks on you for no apparent reason!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Prototype 2 is the typical lackluster sequel if there ever was one. Sure, the graphics are prettier and the gameplay is "refined", but it suffers the burden of being not only a poor port, but something of a shoe-in title. The story is less than great and won't keep you invested in the game. While the game itself is fun, it has the potential to be extremely tedious and sometimes purely boring. The "side missions" are a rinse and repeat formula and strikingly exhausting. Sure, the first few are fun, maybe - but soon they become a real pain. If you're playing the game with an AMD card, you'll have to deal with constant memory leakage, gradually cranking the game's performance down and leaving you with a sad twitching pile of polygons and laggy blur effects. I had to end up downloading a third party application to have the game run smooth and actually have a chance at finishing it without losing my mind. If you're interested in an "open world" superhero game, (the open world is actually not "open" - it's split into districts of fairly small sizes that require fast travel between them; invisible walls, ahoy!) where you're free to run wild and destroy things and throw people, this game is exactly what you're looking for. If you're looking for immersive story and impressive mechanics, steer clear.

Posted: April 30, 2015
												I cannot play this game, I'm mostly just writing this to let others know that this is a♥♥♥♥♥♥port. Stay away from this on PC, avoid it like it has the plague. I honestly would love a refund for my money, and time spent trying to fix something that should have already been fixed.Edit: I did get this to start working with my AMD card, there is a wonderful topic in the discussion board that helped, but that still does not change the fact that I would not recommend buying this on a PC, it crashes frequently, and I've had sound cut out on cutscenes at odd times. As for the game itself the story is actually pretty decent, the game is more of the same of prototype so it is fun at times, but the combat feels lacking compared to the first one, this is partially due to having two powers out at once now, and one button is used for either power. Overall I would say it's average for fun, but if you did kind of enjoy the plot of prototype, I did, then this is not a must play immediately but I say an eventually, like you know three years later.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												I don't usually really like open-world cityscape games, but this keeps a tight focus on giving you an arc of getting new abilities and then using them for a while, and moving on. The only real "open world" aspect is to go collect powerups, which can all be found with minimal hairpulling, which is greatly appreciated.Ultimately this game is a solid beat-em-up, with some sandbox elements; don't expect a lot of variety in terms of alternative things to do. It can be a little samey and drag as you approach the end, but you want to forgive it because the core gameplay usually feels good, and gives you so many options when trying to figure out how to smash through a set of enemies with as much health remaining as possible. It's very clear that they refined the combat system rather than throw on random minigame distractions, and I appreciate the game's sense of focus.I can't recommend it at $40 but if you can get it heavily discounted then it's definitely worth your time.

content:

												Absolutely Great Game!! Yes I have to admit it is "dumbed downed" from the last game, the mainquest and sidequests are easier than the last game and most of your powers and moves dont have a negative trade-off, but the overall fun of game over shadows the weaknesses it has. The graphics are beautiful, everything is sharp and very detailed. The game's focus is on powers and they are just super fun to use. The map is three times bigger than the last game because it includes two other islands to explore. The boss battles are the best part of this game because of their intensity and that compared to the last game instead of upgrading to get powers you get powers by killed a boss. I really recommend this game for anyone who enjoyed the last game and just general sandbox, destruction, powers, mutants type of game.There seemed to be a memory glitch thing going around but i didn't expeirence it.I used a nvidia geforce gtx 670 to play this game.Recommended++++

Just jumping around the city can be fun on it's own, combine that with ridiculous power and upgradeable moves and you will have a good time. Story is easy to follow but I didn't care much for the characters, I much preffered jumping off a roof and then tossing  a car on a group of people. Third person, super here style action, melee and guns, fun boss fights and all around solid action game. This is one of those titles that you can just jump in and mindless wreck stuff for a hour, very satisfying.

												A sandbox isn't very fun without toys. For the FULL version of Prototype 2 you need to buy the RADNET DLC. So, no foot races, rampage type challenges, etc. Not unless you buy the DLC.Otherwise it's a good game, but it was an unwelcome suprise to find afterword that this is the main story and ONLY the main story.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Loads and loads of fun. Prototype 2 took the lessons learned in Prorotype and distilled all of the most intensely fun parts into a new game. Heller is a superb protagonist, and I found myself chuckling at his snide remarks more than a few times. The powers and unlocking were all streamlined from the original. Mercer transitioned perfectly from protagonist to antagonist, and it's beautiful how in-your-face he is right off the start. It really makes the climax that much more intense. Only criticism was that the difficulty felt a bit low. The only time I really felt any pushback was on the final Mercer fight. The rest of the game makes you feel like some kind of symbiote-deity. And that's totally all right. In conclusion, it is a fitting sequel which surpasses the original. Well worth the buy.

content:
Posted: April 16
												$10 game or less only. Never full price. This is a fine $10 game, but that's it. Right off the bat you're faced with nonexistent audio ambiance. I'm trying to tell you that it's completely immersion breaking. The art style is trying to be all "Sin City" and it's done horribly. Ready for combat? Unlike the game's predecessor, you no longer start out wrecking havoc with almost all your abilities as a "taste" of your power to come. The best gameplay intro in one is completely exchanged for a lame 10 min intro filled with bad acting, bad cutscenes, and horrible tutorial pauses. Then you have the STORY. Now, don't let my PC playtime fool you, I know the story. It's a joke. It's cliche one minute and makes no sense the next. You know how the trailer sets you up? Story goes sideways from what you're expecting within the first five minuets. And not in a good way. This game makes me sad, because I absolutely loved the first game. This one is just bad. The combat was already dated when it was released. In 2017 it's almost unplayable combat. It's so clunky. Do NOT expect Bateman, Shadows of Moreawesome, or Witcher combat. Don't expect assassins creed, hitman, or mass effect style combat. No, let me fully INSULT this game by comparing it to an equally horrible game: FABLEYEAH, this game is about on par with the fable trash bag that was released around the same time. Again. $10 or less for collecting purposes only.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												I was happy to get this game at first till I started playing it.  First thing I always do before starting a game is go into options.  That section of the game was broken right of the bat. I wanted to select screen resolution and check key bindings.  None of this was possible.  Started the game I quickly found out when it said use left mouse botton only, the right botton worked.  Then when the game said to use right button to siphon life and restore health, no button anyplace on the keyboard or mouse worked. The game was stuck.  I had to alt + delete to quit the game.  Did some google searching and found lots of issues with this game starting with non Nvidia Gfx cards to changeing mouse configurations.  Meeting the system requirements fully, this should not happen.  So I take my thumbs up on this game back and warn others.  This game is  not worth buying.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												The first issue with this game is that I cannot use my mouse because of weird extreme chopiness which is not an isolated issue, meaning it is not uncommon. Fine, whatever. I have to use my xbox 360 pad which is fine I do not mind that at all. But the big issue which is why I've never finished the game is because it is one of the worst console ports I have ever seen in terms of performance. I have a nice rig where on any games that are not poorly optimized or bad ports, I get a smooth 60fps at max settings @ 1920x1080. This game, no. I get 60fps in it yea but also stuttering from bad optimization/coding. It is still playable and enjoyable for sure, just is distracting where almost all of my other games are not because they perform flawlessly.Besides that crap, this is a very entertaining game. You get super powers and using them to fk people up is awesome and never gets old. You can tear people in half and flatten heads and all kinds of cool ways to kill dudes. It's a big improvement over the first game in terms of quality. Better sound, controls, gameplay, etc. Although just like the first game it's a bad console port job. You can send out a pulse and find guys to consume that give you side missions but it seems like they do not become an option until you finish a certain amount of the story.Port job 4/10. Game 7.5/10

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												To people not familiar with Prototype 1, I recommend it, it's a power fantasy and a lot of fun. There are references to the first game but it's not needed to have a fun time. This game is a Power Fantasy and it does that in spades, you feel powerful. Enjoy. My review below is for people who have played and enjoyed the plot and storyline of the original Prototype. To fans of the original Prototype, this game is about the same. It's a big more organized, with a bit more work put into it. But it has the same progression and feels very much like you are just playing the original Prototype with a few extras added in. If you feel a "Prototype itch" this may be a decent game to pick up if it was heavily discounted, but I generally do not recommend this game. I do not recommend it because the completion of this game left a bad taste in my mouth. I enjoyed the original Protoype, and loved the story and the plot. But this game throws it all away. Because (Spoilers)  Alex Mercer, the original protagonist, is rewritten as a batshit crazy idiot-ball carrying villian who actively pursues the very thing you fought to stop in the original game. Which, as someone who played the first Prototype who enjoyed and got to understand the complex personality of Alex Mercer, I find to be a complete cop-out, and this just thoroughly destroyed my enjoyment of the Prototype franchise.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Prototype 2 at first was hard to really give an opinion on. You play as a marine named James Heller who's basic focus is to kill his family's murderer: Alex Mercer. Heller through 3/4's of the game is a cliche 'I'm just the perfect badass' character. And it's very irritating. No, he is not very emotional past flat out angry. While the anger is understandable, it isn't acceptable to me that a character only really acts on one feeling. You will see Heller in other emotions so don't get me wrong, he isn't the same throughout the whole story (thank God). But it's only about 3 times. Other than that, he's a cocky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that can't go a minute without swearing. As for gameplay, that's where it took me a while. The combat at first is meteocre since you have no abilities. You just mash one button. Once you get a couple abilities that's when it starts to get fun as you can use two abilities at once rather than having to switch so much in the first title. The side missions are rinsed and repeated, but you become more powerful this way and honestly, it never really gets old being able to sneak in and destroy things by morphing into another human you just "ate". They also added a timed side mission where you need to get all the intel canisters before Blackwatch gets their corrupt little hands on them. You only get two mass abilities unfortunately. The first is just the recycled devastator Mercer used. The second I don't want to spoil. I actually like that it takes longer to unlock things in this one. You can't hijack tanks or helicopters nearly as soon as you could in the first, so it makes for more of a challenge. Overall, the gameplay is definitely better than the first, but I do miss the ability to body surf. And I also miss how you dig in and tear up the streets in the first one too. You don't really do that in this one. And if you're curious about the graphics....no they definitely are not better than the first. I run this on maximum settings and it still looks bad compared to the first. But I'm not a person to care as long as the game is solid.As for the story, some say it's deeper than the first. Yeah I can agree with that to a point. The story is very predictable but done decent. Half of the story is told through the important people you steal memories from. I always liked that about Prototype. The end was a cliffhanger and left me wanting more. I hope at some point in the future they decide to make a Prototype 3 to either continue the story or add closure to it. I'd say this game is worth a max of $15 to $20. Better than the first and definitely recommended. But I always feel Prototype could do so much better with the story and immersion. Lets hope they make a Prototype 3 someday and really blow our minds with it.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												I love the Prototype series and having played both of them the second one is definitely the best option on console... ON CONSOLE. Prototype 2 is definitely not worth your money for the PC version, it's a shoddy port that I had problems getting to run (the game has a problem with some HID Hardware meaning that I had to unplug my keyboard in order for the game to run.) and then when it did finally work I was hovering between 30 and 40 FPS and the graphics don't warrant the game dropping below 100 let alone 40 FPS.I can't comment on the port of the original Prototype as I have only played the second one on PC.If you have an Xbox 360 or PS3 I would definitely recommend that you buy it for one of those machines; it provides hours of fun and an unprecedented sense of power. However avoid at all costs if you are planning to buy it on PC.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Let's clarify. I WOULD absolutely recommend this game if it was not so definitely broken.No matter if you have a last gen pc with tons of ram (i have 32GB) and a last gen video card (i use AMD wit 2GB). The game lags and crashes every about 10 minutes. It's just a bad porting.Too bad because there are some aspects in which the game really shines. Graphics are very cool, when the frame rate doesn't drop. Controls are improved, and the overall impression, compared to the first episode, is of that a world which is actually alive (also thanks to the motion capture movements and the improved usability).There are also some ponts where, I think, the game is actually worse than the first chapter, like the start of the game (I liked the "immediately in the game, and the story piece by piece" of the first episode), which I found quite slow. The second episode has a more RPG-like evolution system than the first chapter, making it duller at some ponts (as someone said, you almost cannot chose at all how to evolve your pg, you have to follow very strict guidelines).But the very bad thing is that you cannot at all play this game. Seriously, it's very cool, but it willl just not run in your pc. Too bad, because it would be a great experience.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												It's much better than Prototype 1 but that's a given for a sequel. The game basically plays like Watchdogs, Grand Theft Auto and Saints Row. The most similar one being Saints Row. The game is basically Prototype 1 with all the same powers and abilities but with a black man called Heller. This game is much weaker relative to stronger AAA titles such as Batman. It feels like they took the standard template in the Unreal 3 engine and chugged out a game as fast as possible (You can see the similarities in Saints Row, Blades of Time, Darksiders and Batman). The map has so many different locations but all they do is make you go between bases e.g. Indian 69.The format is basically the same. Go to Area A, kill everything, Go to Area B kill everything. Go to Area A again, kill everything. The latest Saints Row series can get you everything here. High speed sprinting, air dashing, flying and super powers.I would recommend Batman: Arkham Series as a better alternative, it plays in a similar style and everything is better. PROS1. StorylineI think that's the main draw for me.2. Tank warfareDriving the tank and ripping the turret off. Driving an APC and ripping off the TOW launcher.3. Helicopter WarfareHijacking a helicopter and ripping of their missile launchers.4. ExecutionsAlways interesting to see how it's done.5. PowersThis is probably the coolest you have. However, the powers get pretty mundane after a while.a. Clawb. Bladec. Hammerfistd. Bio-bombe. Pack Leaderf. Devastatorg. TendrilsCONS1. AI is dumbThe same problems are ported over from Prototype 1.a. You can land in disguise from the sky and no one will suspect you of being Heller.b. You can break an alert by turning back into Heller once line of sight is broken, despite being a wanted man. c. You can consume an enemy standing next to another enemy if his outline is white. His friend won't even notice him missing.d. Civilians stop panicking if the alert drops down even if there is carnage all arounde. Too easy to break the Alert. Run behind the wall and press F.f. You can fly in the air and no one cares as long as you're in military uniform.g. If you bio-bomb a unit, you can immediately consume him despite being watched.2. Civilian Collateral DamageAre you trying to save the city or destroy it? You can even consume civilians if you want.3. Targetting systemsIt's horrible. You have to aim at specific target by pressing R. There is no snap to lock on. You can't fix and focus on killing 1 opponent. You can't swtich between targets fast enough.4. Bugsa. Sudden death when the infected pustules expand and you're standing on them in the same space.5. Lousy Attack PatternsIt is very repetitive. Block the attack, spike and stun the opponent, then slash. Do the same thing for all creatures, including bosses. You can basically kill everyone with the style. Granted the combat is semi-punishing if you miss the block.6. Repetitive MissionsEvery mission is the same. a. Ping-hunt target A and consume him.b. Destroy the lair by destroying pustulesc. Go on a run and collect stuff from a downed helicopter7. EnvironmentIt is so boring looking at the same NPCs being generated.a. Same civilliansb. Same army trucksc. Funny locations for bases that have the same design8. ChallengesExtremely dumb. There was one in the stadium where you tried to blow up as many Blackwatch units as possible by landing from the air. The Blackwatch units just stand there doing nothing.SUGGESTIONS1. Improve Your TargetingCode in a snap to enemy.2. Stop Copying other Games, Differentiate Yourself MoreThe format is just too similar. Pinging? All of them have it.3. Upgrade the EnvironmentIt's so bland with no backstory or art. Learn from Batman: Arkham Series.4. Stop the Point A to Point BIt's too similar to GTA's open world format.5. Range Combat How about a bio-cannon coming out of your arm?6. Air CombatI mean fighting in the air, not just hijacking a helicopter.7. Smarter AIRefer to the problems in CONS (1).8. More Mechanized unitsBig mechas, exo-suits that are shielded from an instant consume.9. Living City

content:
Posted: February 8
												The gameplay? Fun as hell. Someone described it as a power trip more than a game. What little I played, that was true - and super fun!Unfortunately, good god it is a buggy mess. There was an issue with the third mission (less than half an hour in) where I couldn't complete the objective. The solution? Reducing the game to only using one core. The next time I tried to play, the game just straight up crashed.So, sadly, as fun as what little I played was, it's just not enough to make up for how buggy that is. I don't normally ever have issues with bugs and glitches - some of my favourite games are bethesda's unholy messes. These bugs, though, were game-breaking, and that just didn't feel good.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												First of all let me start off this review by stating the the game shipped broken and was never fixed.  It always had a bad memory leak and certain missions would cause it to crash.  But now since the Omega Drivers release from AMD and the subsequent upgrade to Windows 10 it is time to remove this game from Steam.The game is completely broken.  Under Win 8.1 and the AMD 14.2 drivers you could mostly play until the memory leak ended your fun.  If you decide to run an older OS and even older drivers, you can have fun in the game.  Really it's not a bad game and at times is quite fun!  On a scale of 1 - 100 I would give it a solid 65 with the memory leak lowering the score to 57.Under Windows 10 the game will actually start, but then the memory leak ends the fun after 5 minutes.  Everyone is going to upgrade to Windows 10 for DX12 games.  Thus this game is completely dead.Please Valve remove this game from the Steam Store.  There is no reason to leave abandoned games on your storefront.    I wish Activision had allowed the original development team to patch the game, but alas that's the current state of PC development I suppose.  Release, promote, and run.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
												This game is sadly mediocre. The gameplay is excellent, I really love the variety of powers and ways you can use them, and the aesthetic of the game is really nice, I greatly enjoy the atmosphere. However, the rest of the game really dropped off in quality. The only real quests in the game (I say real as in having some actual plot and background) are the main story quests, which were very fun, but outside of the main questline there is very little to do. In an open world sandbox game like this, that proves quite problematic. I finished the game in about 8 hours, and afterwards found there was really almost nothing to do, the only side missions being repetetive and rather boring, and the only other things being two types of enemy areas and a few collectibles. Also, this game is INCREDIBLY unstable. Every time I played for more than an hour at a time, I consistently had huge frame rate drops and a whole host of glitches, making the game at times completely unplayable. In conclusion, this game has excellent gameplay but not much else. 5.5/10, only buy if on sale.

												Bought this game a while ago when it was on sale and just recently got around to playing it. I know a lot of people are saying they can't play it due to technical issues, but I haven't experienced any issue when playing the game. 3 1/2 years since its release and the grphics are still decent even compared to some of the games released nowadays. The controls are easy and flows very nicely. The gameplay is somewhat easy, nothing can really stop you once you get the hang of the abilities, but the game is very fun. The story is there, but the missions are somewhat repetitive, and the upgrades don't seem very meaningful aside from the evolutions. Game is currently on sale again so now is the time to buy it if you like open world, kill everything games with a bit of stealth. Wouldn't recommend at the original £20 price tag but definitely worth £5.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Prototype 2 is one of my favourite open world games of all time, with a bigger focus on combat and better controls than the first game, this PC version both looks and runs better than the original console versions ever did. Stealth is always an option rather than outright charging into combat, and is sometimes necessary on harder difficulties to get out of a mess, but it's clear the focus of the developers was on causing as much chaos with your nigh-invulnerability as possible. The only con is the story and main character somehow manage to be worse than the first game, but that's never been important to either title in the series in the first place.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												I loved prototype 1, Had tons of hours into it on the console. but this... this is garbage. its plot is rushed and the entirety of the game is grocery missions ad nausium. I swear the designer wanted this to be a racing game because 1/3 of the missions are race against time, where you pick up boxes (and they give you a little time boost) meanwhile being shot out of the sky with rockets. For such a bad♥♥♥♥♥I'm not sure why it takes our hero so long to recover.  I tried, I tried so hard to play this game to the end but it was just such trash I just couldn't. I'm somewhat of a completionist so the 20 hours I have into the game are not straight storyline. I doubt this poorly put together plot even has 20 hours if you run it straight. I am just so disappointed at how poorly this followed up such a great game. Not going to say its the worst sequel I've ever played but its definitely up there.  Honestly, Play the first one, its all you need and don't sully the memory with this poor sequel.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Basically a worse Prototype and a terrible PC port. If you've played Prototype 1, stick with that. If not and you're considering this, hit back immediately and check out Prototype 1.Good:-Retains the fun gameplay aspects of Prototype 1Bad:-Retains the frustrating gameplay aspects of Prototype 1 (shoddy targetting, clunky/unresponsive controls, cheap♥♥♥♥♥enemy attacks), and makes some of them worse-One of the worst optimized PC ports ever made. Dont expect to run this well without a current generation video card-Story is so bad it's actually painful. You play as a thuglyfe meathead with no redeeming qualities; whose entire vocabulary consists of about 10 words including "♥♥♥♥♥", "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥", and "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥". Your enemies include a PMC called Blackwatch that is so excessively evil, that African rebels who♥♥♥♥♥♥and murder whole villages of women and children on a daily basis would consider them overthetop. There's also Alex Mercer who you play as in the first Prototype, who has also turned completely evil for reasons I'm not even sure were fully explained. The side characters are all forgetable, because you're probably already skipping through the story ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t before you start to have a thought about any of them.-Story missions are boring are repetitive. Massive over abundance of stupid "infiltrate generic military base by stealth consuming a commander"-Character/ability progression is slow, inconsistent, and over-simplified. Upgrades consist almost entirely of basic stat/damage boosts, many of which don't make much of a difference.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												This is a first impression review, and as such you should only consider this from the view point of someone who hasn't seen much of this game. But what I have seen is downright atrocious. This is one of the worst PC ports I've played, and right now it isn't worth a penny until it gets fixed.I regret paying even spending £5 on it, it's has the most unstable frame rate drops I've encountered, struggling to hit 30, then plummeting down to 5 fps without explanation. But it's ok, it's not unpredictably buggy, because it happens constantly, regardless of what I'm doing.It's so bad that the game becomes almost impossible to control, and I wasn't able to play any more than a few minuets before getting a headache. Because of the poor K&M controls it's best to play this with a game pad, then, and only then is this game remotely manageable. But from a design point of view it seems to fall for the usual mistakes that a lot of major release games do, the opening of the game gives you no control, holding you hand all the way through a series of frustrating QTE's, that you can't even fail because time stops, so you can sit under the fist of a giant monster for 5 minutes while it waits for you to click, this is Rambo: The Video Game level of design (but don't worry, you still get an achievement at the end of that level... >.> )I heartily recommend that you don't buy this game for any money, unless you want to spend you valuable time fiddling with community made patches trying to get this broken mess working, because this game has not been patched by the developers or Activision after 2 years.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												Well, first things first.  I'm not a professional reviewer or anything, just another gamer.  I played the original Prototype all the way through, and I thoroughly enjoyed it.  While it started out easy, it got harder and harder the more time I put into it.  By the end of the game the strike teams could harass me repeatedly, and without careful positioning, they could lower my health to dangerous levels or even kill me.  Groups of Hunters were almost as difficult in the end of the game as they were in the beginning.   I particularly enjoyed the story of the first Prototype.  Alex Mercer's character fascinated me from the moment I learned what he truly became after the outbreak at Penn Station.  You're probably wondering why I'm talking about the first game in a review for the second.  It's to provide contrast.After I finished Prototype, I moved on to Prototype 2, as I had bought them together.  I was mildly irritated by a few of the default controls, like how the toggle Disguise button is now F, which was the stealth consume menu/military disguise power menu, and how the new targeting button was the old power wheel selection.  I was able to remap the keys to be more similar to the older Prototype's controls, which made the game much easier to get used to.  Prototype 2 takes advantage of its open world much more than the original did, with collectibles (black boxes) and little mini-missions (field ops and infection lairs) that reward you for their completion with perks, like making him repel all bullets, take reduced damage, increase the range of his melee attacks, and power up charge attacks for each of his virus powers.  While these are very enjoyable, they lower the overall game difficulty immensely.  The disguise/stealth system has been overhauled, with the suspicion meter actually moving up based on your actions in front of the military.  It's also much easier to evade strike teams; when you break their line of sight, toggling your disguise makes them stop and look for you, instead of pursuing you to the ends of the earth even if they can't see you, like they did in the original Prototype.  The whole game world also looks more vibrant, with some areas actually looking like a city people live in, complete with angry protestors and anti-military and anti-Blacklight posters and graffiti, while other areas look like the devastated hellholes they're supposed to be, crawling with infected mutants and screaming civilians desperately trying to escape the clutches of bloodthrirsty monsters.  While most of the animations are the same as the ones from the first Prototype, they still look smooth and believable, and still make you feel that the main character is superhuman.  I also enjoyed the new Hunt system (viral sonar), which makes finding targets satisfying and interactive.Now for the things I didn't like.  I absolutely HATED the new main character, James Heller.  The beginning of the game makes you think that he's a family man gone mad with grief and rage after the avoidable deaths of his wife and daughter at the hands of the second outbreak of the Mercer virus, but after the first few minutes, it's incredibly clear that that assumption is false.  He's more like a walking stereotype, the "Angry Black Man" stereotype to be specific.  He's incredibly foul-mouthed, with each few minutes of the game laced with profanity that sounds like it was written by a middle-schooler.  He lacks the amoral qualities of Alex Mercer, even though he's doing the same terrorist-like activities; most of the time he thinks he's doing things to help people, when really he's doing more harm than good.  It's doesn't seem to be intended, as a quirk of his personality, only lazy writing and bad character personality design.  He feels two-dimensional, like a caricature.  His sole motivations throughout the entire game seem to be rage and anger, nothing more.  He's mentioned his family all of 4-5 times during the entire time I've played the game, and seems to care more about killing random people for random things than actually getting revenge for his family's deaths.  I also immensely disliked the changes they made to the throwing and targeting systems.  It's far harder to lock on to specific enemies than it needs to be; they have to be right in front of you to be able to easily lock onto them, and anything else requires careful positioning and small movements to target anything that's farther away.  Linked with that, the hitboxes of rooftops are larger than they appear, which makes it very hard to throw objects from rooftops unless you have a decently upgraded jump, or the target is positioned in such a way that it's easy to lock on to and nothing is in the way.  Also, so far in the game, the only thing I've learned from the story is that Blackwatch is a horrible organization.  That's about it.  There is no more character development for Heller, just him learning about some atrocity that Blackwatch soldiers have comitted.  The final thing I dislike about it is the overall dumbing down of  the combat system in the game.  I know it's getting more and more common for games these days, but it's just pathetic at times.  In the first Prototype, to dodge you had to hold Shift while pressing a movement key, and during the roll you were susceptible to damage and relied on positioning to be able to set up attacks once the roll was complete.  Now, in Prototype 2, all you have to do to dodge is press Space, and you somersault over them and have a clear opening to their undefended backs.  It takes no skill beyond pressing a button at the right time, and it even tells you when you need to press it.  Hunters used to be dangerous, even after you could grapple them, as long as they were in packs, but now they're barely threatening at all, and even the super-soldiers that Blackwatch sends after you are now only a minor annoyance.  They're supposed to have been designed specifically to kill you, yet after a few damage and defense mutations, they can barely scratch you, and can easily be killed, even when they're backed up by helicopters and tanks and other super-soldiers.  Oh, they also radically change Alex Mercer's personality, which was one of the things I disliked most about Prototype 2.  He becomes incredibly hypocritical and an all-around scumbag instead of an amoral self-serving mutant.  He was hard to like in the first game, but at least he was semi-relatable.  Now he's just as two-demensional as Heller, only serving the role of antagonist with a subpar explanation as to why.  There is little to no explanation as to what caused his rapid and extreme personality shift.  I haven't fully completed the game, but looked up the full plot, since his character was bugging me, and I was about 99.9999% sure of what was going to happen in the end less than halfway through the game.I know I listed more negative things than positive, but I don't really dislike Prototype 2.  It's just that it feels like it was made by a seperate group of people than the first game.  If you're looking for a game similar to the first, I'd recommend trying the inFAMOUS series for the Playstation 3 and 4 before you try Prototype 2.  It's not a bad game, but it's different enough from the first game to make it less fun to play.  It would almost be better to play Prototype 2 only, or at least first, and just watch a recap of the first game's plot in the menu to understand the events in the current game.  It would probably lessen your disappointment.  Overall, I think Prototype 2 puts in some good changes to the series, but at the cost of overall game difficulty, bad plot and characters, and questionable tweaks to the existing game system.  I think, objectively, it deserves a 6.5 at the lowest, and a 7.5 at the highest.  If you enjoyed the first game, you'll probably like Prototype 2, but you'll have to overlook its obvious flaws in order to do so.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												Bought this and Prototype in a steam sale a while back, just got around to playing it... and it is absolutely *plagued* with technical issues.  The framerate chugs, the audio lags behind the video in cutscenes, and the inputs are severly delayed out of box.At first, the game wasn't even playable.  After rolling my drivers back to a version that's severly out of date, I managed to gain enough control to get past the menu screen.  It was fine for a while, but having several enemies on screen still caused the framerate to chug - even with everything set to "low" or "off".My machine has run much more recent/intense games without missing a beat, so I have trouble believing the issue is on my end:================================================AMD FX 8320 3.5 Ghz 4 Physical/ 8 Virtual Cores32GB RAMAMD Radeon 6950 (2GB DDR5, 1408 Stream Processors, DirectX11================================================Don't buy this game - save your money and your sanity.

												Basically the same game: With only a couple more weapons added and a different protagonist who has the exact same powers and skills as the 1st just now with a different skin and voice. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												Overall 6/10Gamers know whether a game has good replay value within the first 10 minutes of playing, by that time if the mechanics of a game don't capture your imagination, you can forget replay value. I'm a very positive person and I'd like to start by saying that if there ever was a Prototype 3, I would play it and give the series another chance to redeem itself, so dear develompent team working on Prototype 3 and development team who produced Prototype 2; please review some notes below in regards to why Prototype 2 sucked, and what was good about it.-The reason Prototype 2 sucked: The mechanics and controls were nowhere near as fluid as the first installment of the game(starting out), nor did they emulate the controls of the first game very well. The game does not feel as 'quick paced' as the first. What I mean by this is that even turning around is too slow, running up buildings I feel like some fat guy with a corn cob shoved up his butt, trying to race to the nearest toilet, casually. Gamers need that 'parkour' feel that the first game had without the fat guy running to the toilet feel the second game has. Your gamers want to feel like ninjas, Super Hero Ninja Samurai Monks(title in development) running through the city, thumping into people and body checking them just to see them slowly stand up and act like nothing happened.  The camera controls felt a little laggy for default, and sometimes did't work at all when trying to get an outward view while running up a building, it was very frustrating trying to fight the first 'Pink Hulk guy'when you changed the dodging mechanics that the first game had. I mean, are you guys even gamers? You do realize that you DON'T need to change essential game functions like that to create a great sequel? Anyway, besides the controls there were several other problems with the game that was basically annoying to sit through and act like I care: The story was way too linear, and the intro/tutorial was too long, and should have had an obvious 'skip' option for the experienced Prototype One players, and if there was an option to skip the nearly hour to two hour long intro tutorial garbage, I couldn't find it. Thats one thing top gaming companies have a problem with, turning videogames into an interactive movie that you have to sit through, thats one thing that destroyed my joy for the Assasins Creed titles. I'm sorry I'm the type of gamer that needs to hear my objectives and story while I move around and goof off, its more emmersive (its one gameplay feature that Doom 3 and half-life did very well, and I am hoping to play the latest iteration of these games also.) Character didn't feel as powerful when landing, climbing and picking up objects. There were much bigger and more pronounced textures and effects in the first Prototype when landing and running up buildings(the cracks on the walls and holes in the ground left from contact with his powerful limbs.) This was a particularly satisfying touch to the first game, makes you feel like you can break through anything(without leaving the destruction around for too long.) The way levelling your character worked: I prefer the Evolution Points method, seeing that you have hundreds of thousands of 'something' on the HUD when your playing as a super hero, and then spending it all, has its appeal. It has a certain appeal in a lot of games actually, makes you feel more accomplished.Did I mention that the intro tutorial was TOO long, limited, and drawn out??What Prototype 2 did right: Explosions worked pretty well, but thats one feature that is easy to make look good. The boost wave effect when you hold down the run button was a nice touch, but somehow wasn't the right kind of emphasis on his actual speed in the intro.The overall textural appearance of the wolverine ability was much nicer and cleaner, and the fighting style for that super power wasn't bad either.The new enemy types were a great and welcome addition, namely birds and other land creatures. Its nice when game sequals give you a fresh variety of enemy types to combat.I liked the effect of the hunting ability, the radar sense was pretty cool, but I think it would have been better if the minimap was involved in the hunting ability, then you wouldn't have to be required to get to a really high building just to seek out targets. Gamers like the freedom of choosing how they execute a search, as long as the enemy/target general location is easily determined.Like I said, I really hope for a Prototype 3, And don't give me this 'theres too many super hero games out there' crap, the super hero genre is alive and you have a whole class of gamers waiting to play the newest original title. By original I mean, NOT a Disney/Marvel mashup,but a game like Prototype with its unique querks and storyline.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												The visual engines of both Prototype games behave in a strange manner:1. They need to run at 60 frames per second on 60 Hertz to have smooth motion, were it not for the insane amounts of stuttering. This stuttering looks very much like an extremely severe case of microstutter, yet I only run a single GPU setup (1 x GTX 780 TI).2. Running the games beyond 60 fps (either through disabling the vsync or running at higher Hz) make them look like a 30 fps game. It looks like the engine repeats every frame even though any framerate counter will state that the games run smoothly at any Hz rate the monitor is set. (eg. 100 fps on a 100 Hz display, but it looks exactly like running a constant 50 fps on 100 Hz.)Both engine faults give me a headache when I try to play the games.I've tried every "fix" I could find on the internet (including disabling all HID devices, running at the lowest in-game graphics settings, adding command line parameters, setting processor affinity, using the resolution fix .dll, etc.) and none worked for me.So I know this isn't much of a review of the game itself. It might be good, but I never got to experience it myself because of these technical issues which I admit being sensitive to. Therefore, I can hardly recommend the game, now can I? I did, after all, not have a fun time playing this game.As such I feel I need to not recommend it. You might not have issues with it however, so keep that in mind. Yet, I still wanted to write these words of warning to those few people who might have issues with this game if smooth motion is kind of a must for them, or to those who loathe bad PC ports in general.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												Overall 6/10Gamers know whether a game has good replay value within the first 10 minutes of playing, by that time if the mechanics of a game don't capture your imagination, you can forget replay value. I'm a very positive person and I'd like to start by saying that if there ever was a Prototype 3, I would play it and give the series another chance to redeem itself, so dear develompent team working on Prototype 3 and development team who produced Prototype 2; please review some notes below in regards to why Prototype 2 sucked, and what was good about it.-The reason Prototype 2 sucked: The mechanics and controls were nowhere near as fluid as the first installment of the game(starting out), nor did they emulate the controls of the first game very well. The game does not feel as 'quick paced' as the first. What I mean by this is that even turning around is too slow, running up buildings I feel like some fat guy with a corn cob shoved up his butt, trying to race to the nearest toilet, casually. Gamers need that 'parkour' feel that the first game had without the fat guy running to the toilet feel the second game has. Your gamers want to feel like ninjas, Super Hero Ninja Samurai Monks(title in development) running through the city, thumping into people and body checking them just to see them slowly stand up and act like nothing happened.  The camera controls felt a little laggy for default, and sometimes did't work at all when trying to get an outward view while running up a building, it was very frustrating trying to fight the first 'Pink Hulk guy'when you changed the dodging mechanics that the first game had. I mean, are you guys even gamers? You do realize that you DON'T need to change essential game functions like that to create a great sequel? Anyway, besides the controls there were several other problems with the game that was basically annoying to sit through and act like I care: The story was way too linear, and the intro/tutorial was too long, and should have had an obvious 'skip' option for the experienced Prototype One players, and if there was an option to skip the nearly hour to two hour long intro tutorial garbage, I couldn't find it. Thats one thing top gaming companies have a problem with, turning videogames into an interactive movie that you have to sit through, thats one thing that destroyed my joy for the Assasins Creed titles. I'm sorry I'm the type of gamer that needs to hear my objectives and story while I move around and goof off, its more emmersive (its one gameplay feature that Doom 3 and half-life did very well, and I am hoping to play the latest iteration of these games also.) Character didn't feel as powerful when landing, climbing and picking up objects. There were much bigger and more pronounced textures and effects in the first Prototype when landing and running up buildings(the cracks on the walls and holes in the ground left from contact with his powerful limbs.) This was a particularly satisfying touch to the first game, makes you feel like you can break through anything(without leaving the destruction around for too long.) The way levelling your character worked: I prefer the Evolution Points method, seeing that you have hundreds of thousands of 'something' on the HUD when your playing as a super hero, and then spending it all, has its appeal. It has a certain appeal in a lot of games actually, makes you feel more accomplished.Did I mention that the intro tutorial was TOO long, limited, and drawn out??What Prototype 2 did right: Explosions worked pretty well, but thats one feature that is easy to make look good. The boost wave effect when you hold down the run button was a nice touch, but somehow wasn't the right kind of emphasis on his actual speed in the intro.The overall textural appearance of the wolverine ability was much nicer and cleaner, and the fighting style for that super power wasn't bad either.The new enemy types were a great and welcome addition, namely birds and other land creatures. Its nice when game sequals give you a fresh variety of enemy types to combat.I liked the effect of the hunting ability, the radar sense was pretty cool, but I think it would have been better if the minimap was involved in the hunting ability, then you wouldn't have to be required to get to a really high building just to seek out targets. Gamers like the freedom of choosing how they execute a search, as long as the enemy/target general location is easily determined.Like I said, I really hope for a Prototype 3, And don't give me this 'theres too many super hero games out there' crap, the super hero genre is alive and you have a whole class of gamers waiting to play the newest original title. By original I mean, NOT a Disney/Marvel mashup,but a game like Prototype with its unique querks and storyline.

Plus, other courageous reviews present a depth n' detail storyline.I'm here to help those suffering from the ATI and AMD issues from the severely poor port that I experienced.The original prototype I felt added a significant Replay value, and that is the winning poll in my vote. In playing Prototype 2, I see it was a bit rushed and perhaps that is why devs abandoned it. {Being under economic pressure can cause serious stress attacks.}Nevertheless, it was fun, but I only feel like going back and playing the original...even in it's crusty old black and white building state. Now, for the ATI and AMD users, this is a MUST, if you are a hardcore Prototype, Infamous type player then I suggest getting game with these programs:FOREMOST TO DO - GO TO Steam Users' Forums > Steam Game Discussions > M - P > Prototype series [ FIX ] Prototype 2 Radeon Memory Leak Lag Fix by Kompster, as this fix may not help everyone.1. RadeonPro - allows you to run this game or otherwise you suffer severe memory loss/loop - both on your PC and in your mind! - Thanks to Kompster!2. content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Basically a worse Prototype and a terrible PC port. If you've played Prototype 1, stick with that. If not and you're considering this, hit back immediately and check out Prototype 1.Good:-Retains the fun gameplay aspects of Prototype 1Bad:-Retains the frustrating gameplay aspects of Prototype 1 (shoddy targetting, clunky/unresponsive controls, cheap♥♥♥♥♥enemy attacks), and makes some of them worse-One of the worst optimized PC ports ever made. Dont expect to run this well without a current generation video card-Story is so bad it's actually painful. You play as a thuglyfe meathead with no redeeming qualities; whose entire vocabulary consists of about 10 words including "♥♥♥♥♥", "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥", and "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥". Your enemies include a PMC called Blackwatch that is so excessively evil, that African rebels who♥♥♥♥♥♥and murder whole villages of women and children on a daily basis would consider them overthetop. There's also Alex Mercer who you play as in the first Prototype, who has also turned completely evil for reasons I'm not even sure were fully explained. The side characters are all forgetable, because you're probably already skipping through the story ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t before you start to have a thought about any of them.-Story missions are boring are repetitive. Massive over abundance of stupid "infiltrate generic military base by stealth consuming a commander"-Character/ability progression is slow, inconsistent, and over-simplified. Upgrades consist almost entirely of basic stat/damage boosts, many of which don't make much of a difference.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												This is a first impression review, and as such you should only consider this from the view point of someone who hasn't seen much of this game. But what I have seen is downright atrocious. This is one of the worst PC ports I've played, and right now it isn't worth a penny until it gets fixed.I regret paying even spending £5 on it, it's has the most unstable frame rate drops I've encountered, struggling to hit 30, then plummeting down to 5 fps without explanation. But it's ok, it's not unpredictably buggy, because it happens constantly, regardless of what I'm doing.It's so bad that the game becomes almost impossible to control, and I wasn't able to play any more than a few minuets before getting a headache. Because of the poor K&M controls it's best to play this with a game pad, then, and only then is this game remotely manageable. But from a design point of view it seems to fall for the usual mistakes that a lot of major release games do, the opening of the game gives you no control, holding you hand all the way through a series of frustrating QTE's, that you can't even fail because time stops, so you can sit under the fist of a giant monster for 5 minutes while it waits for you to click, this is Rambo: The Video Game level of design (but don't worry, you still get an achievement at the end of that level... >.> )I heartily recommend that you don't buy this game for any money, unless you want to spend you valuable time fiddling with community made patches trying to get this broken mess working, because this game has not been patched by the developers or Activision after 2 years.
