number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Prototpe 2 feels like a much better version of prototype. Some examples: what i didn't like in prototype was that you have an open world but nothing is really happening in this world besides the military and the infected. The civilians were just wandering around pointlessly. In prototype 2 the civilians talk to each other about the infection and about blackwatch killing civilians which drags you as the player way deeper in this scenario.Another thing i didn' like in prototype was that the combat wasn't really dynamic you chose one power at the start and if you wanted to change it you needed to access the menu. In prototype 2 you can select 2 powers on your 2 mouse keys. For example you can make left click a claw attack and right click a tendril attack which improves the combat system alot because you can now be more creative in killing enemies.In prototype 2 the NY is divided in 3 different zones depending on the level of infection in this zone. There is the green, yellow and red zone. All these zones feel unique because of the way the artists designed them. For example in the yellow zone you got demonstrations against blackwatch and civilians in cages while in the red zone you find infected wandering around everywhere a lot of destroyed buildings.In prototype 2 the evolution of the protagonist isn't done with spending ep for new moves anymore. It's more like in a RPG you get ep and after you have enough you get a level up which grants you a point that you can spend in different categories.There are also other "mutations" that you get after completing certain events in a package or finishing //BLACKNET-Missions.Your powers and skills to work with weapons or vehicles get upgraded by consuming marked targets with an "strong-arm-symbol" over their head.To sum it all up prototype 2 is a different appraoch to the prototype franchise then prototype. If you liked prototype 1 you should definately play prototype 2.

												I give this game an 8.5/10. As someone who isn't a big fan of open world games like this, I can't stop playing it. The world is massive, I haven't come across a single terrible mission, there's constant opportunity to improve your character and unlock new abilities. Not to mention just traversing the city is fun on its own (running up the side of buildings, hijacking vehicles, gliding from rooftop to rooftop). This game improves upon the first in every way. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												Prototype 2 is basically just more of the same. Some game mechanics have been slightly tweaked, but overall it's the same game with a different character.The story is paper thin and aside from the occasional insight into Blackwatch and the science teams fighting the infection, the story might as well not be there at all. Heller, like Mercer in the original game, has absolutely no regard for human life and basically turns into a killing machine the moment the game starts. Except for one situation in the game where he suddenly shows compassion for one single person. His one-liners are enjoyable but as a protagonist he does very little else to wow you.The virus, mutations, upgrades, weapons and shape shifting are the bread and butter of this game. 99% of the time you will be hacking, slashing and impaling Blackwatch soldiers and infected alike with your shape shifting blades and other goodies. As you progress through the game these weapons will become more and more powerful. If you take the time to do side missions this gets to a point where Heller becomes completely overpowered and is able to easily kill anything that gets in his way. Some upgrades even make you immune to small arms fire, making it possible to ignore the majority of the military all together while avoiding rockets.While this kind of power is very fun to play around with, it takes away just about any challenge the game had left to offer. Any enemy that can't be killed in 3 hits can easily be avoided and with a huge surplus of consumeable people around you will never (ever) run out of health. While I played the game on Normal, I can't imagine the game being any more challenging on Hard.It's still a very fun game to play around in. But if you are looking for a solid story or a game that offers a challenge then you best keep searching. This is basically a hack and slash version of GTA and nothing more. Recommended to get when it's on sale.

												the two major flaws in the first prototype were the glitchy stuttery cutscenes (even on high end gaming computers there was no way to generate enough FPS to get it smooth) and the tendency to just throw crap on the screen to make a challenge more difficult  improved graphics, improved gameplay, cutscenes play correctly the major flaws of the original release have been addressed and other than the occasional NPC stuck in a wall i havent seen much glitching.   glad this game finally went on sale as $39.99 for a discontinued title from a shuttered publisher was pretty steep.  the new abilities are fun, and the story seems pretty interesting.  i havent finished the game but it looks like our hero from the first episode might be doing a heel turn in the prototype 2.  unless the second half of the game is just an unmitigated disaster i would recommend this as a fun hack and slash wreckage and destruction title!  buy it on sale though, its not a $40 game.  its just a shame there isnt going to be a part 3 since the publisher went under.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												Essentially building on the gameplay of the first, Prototype 2 succeeds and fails on roughly the same merits. Fancier black and white cutscenes can't disguise a poor story that trods on the character development of the first, while many of the new methods of unlocking all your slimy, spike-covered evolutions are now tied to list-checking side-missions. The air of requirement on these side missions turns them from a fun diversion in the first to a tedious chore in the second. However, the gameplay itself is, in its way, improved. The list of mutations lost Muscle-Mass but gained the Tendrils, and underachievers like Whip-Fists and Hammerhands gained noticable improvements. Graphical fidelity is improved (but of course, it's the PC port that does it), but it's still roughly more of the same. The change in environments is nice, but in some ways a sour note. In the first game, the ownership of various districts shifted back and forth between military, civilian, and infected ground. Now, the game simply divides into three islands, an infected hellhole, a military lockdown, and a civilian slum. While this does mean that they can sculpt the three types into a much more varied experience, it requires tedious travel between them through abusing either the accidental fast-travel of playing the side-missions from the menu, or running to the few places one can hitch a helicopter from island to island.A game I'd only recommend on sale, but would still recommend.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I'll make this short and to the point:AchievementsThis is one of the few games that works gathering achievements into story progression thus making it nearly impossible to miss as you progress.  Other than that, it has an even amount of progression and skill based achievements that will keep you engaged.StoryIt plays like a mini-scifi/horror tv series that is a bit on the raw side with good acting and cut sequences.CombatIt is extremely fluid and flexible and will appeal to both digital samurai and button mashers. However, this is NOT the type of game you play with a keyboard and mouse...GraphicsThey're not the best nor are they the worse - it's a happy medium considering it's a sandbox environment. Load times are near instant on medium systems and there is virtually no FPS choke points that I've encountered despite the hundreds upon hundreds of zombies roaming the city...Overall, this is one of those weekend warrior games that will keep you entertained and decently challenged for a good 30 hours...That’s if you’re going for 100% completion.However, my only complaint is that you can't reach 100% completion without starting a new game on insane mode and racing through the storyline. I bought the DLC thinking that I could finish things up but alas, the EP gains are null. So in other words, buy the dlc for the mini games (which are challenging and fun), but start a 2nd playthrough on insane mode (which inherits everything you've completed in past game modes and only takes a couple of hours) for the extra EP if you want to complete it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												 I loved the first Prototype, I even bought Prototype 2's collector's edition for Xbox 360. It's sitting on a shelf above my head right now. This is a fun game, no doubt about that. Once you actually gain all your powers, you start to feel like a god, but the game has a natural progression. You start with your fists, gain a power, gain more power, until you can stand up to your maker. My only gripe is where Alex Mercer from the first game felt like a depressed teen with super powers, Heller feels so angry that I expect him to turn into the Hulk so I can play Ultimate Destruction. Literally every line from him is "..♥♥♥♥..." "♥♥♥♥♥" "♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; "swear word". I understand his family was taken from him, and that is one of the most traggic things in a person's life is when your family is killed. But, seriously? Almost every line? I can't fault the game in its gameplay as the devs really took care of what they worked on, but Heller felt overly angry at everything. A character who is a part of Mercer's "evolved" *spoilers I guess* is helping Heller from inside Gentek to try and bring down Mercer as she's in it for herself. All Heller does is say "you got me intel that could get you turned into goop or experimented like a lab rat? ♥♥♥♥♥, get more!" At least try and be a bit more friendly to the only Evolved who seems to be on your side, is in a very advantageous position and in a way you could spot for miles away betray you at the end to get into Mercer's good graces. The soundtrack is great, offering some very emotional and slow melodies or fast paced tracks that really feel like this is something to be hyped over. The voice acting is also very good, hitting the right marks as you do feel for these characters, but Heller sounds like he's Bruce Banner from "The Avengers" where he reveals that he's always angry, but he shows it all the time.In closing, I'd say if you weren't a fan of the previous one, then this is a pass, but if you're like me and loved the first one, then this is a buy. Just remember though, Heller does tend to swear in almost every sentence, I think Prototype 2 beat "♥♥♥♥- a documentary on the word" for amount of times he said "♥♥♥♥."

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												Loved this game. Yes it has a memory leak for pc but dont let that discourage you! The game changes up some things from the first game that didnt work well. One was the minigames; screw those and just have them integrated into the missions. Make enemies easier to consume when they're at low health. Have new game changing abilities, all of which you will use and be encouraged to use. A little more help to get you through the game easier. It might seem like a little much at first but believe me as someone who is a slow learner, it's worthwhile. I loved the perk system and level up system. Unfortunately there isnt a counter for body count anymore or any reason to randomly kill military but you get everything with the second playthrough as long as you do some searching around the city. One suggestion that I wish I knew going into the game: THE MAP HELPS YOU FIND BLACK BOXES, DENS, AND FIELD TEAMS! The general area is pinged on the map if you have something undiscovered. Use this info to your advantage! It can be found under collectibles in the map tabs.My favorite ability is the Bio-Bomb! I literally spent 2 hours alone playing around with it. There is also a RadNet change to it that allows you to kick those you bio-bomb square in the♥♥♥♥♥toward your target! It's fantastic. It allows me to stealth missions easier while removing detectors to move around easier. I used it a lot to stealth kill tanks and helicopters ahead of time for missions. Totally the most useful skill out of combat and can be used for fun in combat as well.Happy hunting!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												This game has plenty going for it. Good story, character building, reaction times, and who doesn't like killing diseased zombies. It's kind of like GTA super villain edition. Where does the character Heller place himself in the midst of vast corruption in the government, corporation, and the rebels? You can explore, drive tanks, fly helicopters, fly (glide), use weapons which are attached and detached with special manouvers. Now for the Con, and it's a big one... It would seem when they ported the game over to PC, the developers didn't think about memory management. A memory leak!!! The application seems to handle up to a 4gb ram allocation. Anything more and it locks up and abnormally ends. I have 16 gb and really enjoyed Prototype I so this wouldn't stop me. I found you can keep an eye on the physical memory in task manager, displayed on your second monitor. Prior to that threshold (for me it was at 7.1gb (you will need to identify your own as you may have more or less applications running than I do), you can alt+tab out of the game and then go back in. In doing it this way, windows will clean up the memory leaked until it builds up again. It definately adds a challenge.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												Bloody FunIf you want to be a super-powered behemoth with no regard for human life, tearing through a devastated NYC with an assortment of violent super-powers, then look no further. If you played the first one you'll know what to expect, just bigger, and more. I found this game fun, neither too challenging nor too easy. It didn't make me think, it didn't ask me to make choices, it just gave me things to smash in hilarious and exciting ways. The characters and plot are laughably bad, and I actually really enjoyed them in a B-movie kind of way. About half way through I did start skipping through every cinematic, but this in no way affected my understanding or enjoyment of the game.A great game to play after a hard day if you want to just turn off and laugh (hopefully with a friend, the co-op was surprisingly fun!)

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												Prototype 2 is similar to Prototype "overall" - ie: an open world sandbox where it's fun just doing whatever you want. The main problem with Prototype was that the first special offensive ability gained was pretty much all you needed to use for the rest of the game, so the other offensive abilities don't get much use. Prototype 2 is much more 'balanced' than the first in this respect, but now the game holds off giving you the (overpowered) offensive ability from the first game, until "after" the final battle - meaning that there is nobody left worth using it on!That aside, it is a fun sandbox game with just enough to keep people coming back after the campaign is completed...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 7, 2012
												Worthy sequel to the 1st game. Fixes the few annoying bits of the 1st game (the repetitive base infiltration segments that ended up all feeling the same) and adds even more enjoyable & destructive modes. The story is nearly as good as in the original due to fact while it doesn't have the same crazy twist, you do get to turn the tables on the previous anti-hero and main character of the previous game as Alex Mercer is now the main villain and you end up having a kick♥♥♥♥♥epic battle against him.I also have to say that I'm a bit biased as there are very few games where the main character is black and well-done, and being a black man I'm always looking for more cultural diversity in my games. So it helps that while being a one dimensional-character James Heller is pretty decent as far as characters go. It would have been nice though to have him interact more with his daughter as at times it doesn't feel like she's a big part of his life or the main reason why he's fighting and he can come off as just another really angry black man.The gameplay is akin to that in the first game as you can run up buildings, toss cars, glide across rooftops and from on end of the city to the other as you become more powerful and run at such speeds through the streets of NYC that the ground cracks under your feet and you feel that sense of mass and speed as you collide with NPCs and other elements in the environment and send them flying! Being a superhero (cause face it, that's basically what you are) rarely ever felt this good :DThe combat is also a lot of fun as your various virus-related abilities make you feel increasingly powerful and badass and you can carve (literally lol!) a path of utter destruction through your enemies and the city of NY. It's a joy to experiment with your increasing array of lethal abilities and learning what works best against which enemy and being able to weaponize grenade launchers and other weaponry that you literally rip from vehicles is a blast xD8.75/10

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												I didn't find this game as rewarding as the first. While there was considerable expansion to the powers and the abilities, the game length was somewhat short. The storyline was not very cathartic, but that is a completely subjective judgement.Pros:Good GraphicsFast ActionGood use of standard blend of powers.Open worldCons: Seems to be having trouble running on modern systems.Open World is very static.Side Missions become repetitive very quickly.Confusing storyline delivered through questionable menu.All in all, the whole game seems like a redo of the first, with less work put into matching the story to the side missions and using the latter as a generic skeleton to hang a thin coating of story over. Saints Row IV did similar. The people are even more distant and inaccessible from the players point of view, and the game's response to the player is limited, so it becomes very simple to determine what will happen, and the military always seems to be keen to open fire on you often sometimes without reason.Is it fun? Yes. Is it worth the price?I would get it on sale.A big sale.

												Heads up: there is a memory leak issue with this game, but a fix is on the forums. Having said that, even /with/ the leak unfixed I would still reccomend this over Prototype 1. -The city is smaller but everything is much more varied and vibrant and interesting so its more enjoyable to move around in. -Combat is less obnoxious and you can fluidly mix in different mutation attacks rather than select one 'mode' at a time-Upgrades are less unique than in P1, but since half the interesting stuff you would have bought in P1 is given to you either by default or during the story...-Side missions are way more fun!-Rnet lets you get different skins and screw with the game's physics.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 9, 2012
												If you like sandbox games then you'll love this as it is so addictive.The first Prototype was fun but ultimately repetitive such that I got bored of it less than half-way through. This sequel takes everything that was enjoyable about the original game, i.e. the cool power-ups and mayhem you could cause with them, but manages to maintain the interest for much longer, thanks to constant rewards and more variety in the missions. Add in Challenge modes and collectibles and you have one fun game that might not win many Game of the Year awards come the turn of 2012 but will definitely be one of your favourites nevertheless. I guarantee it.Graphics are an improvement on the PS2-era visuals of the original and the engine does a fine job of handling dozens of enemies and explosions on the screen at once. I especially love the way that the game shows a scene from the game running behind the main menu and as soon as you select Continue it jumps straight into the game... no loading at all!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I'll make this short and to the point:AchievementsThis is one of the few games that works gathering achievements into story progression thus making it nearly impossible to miss as you progress.  Other than that, it has an even amount of progression and skill based achievements that will keep you engaged.StoryIt plays like a mini-scifi/horror tv series that is a bit on the raw side with good acting and cut sequences.CombatIt is extremely fluid and flexible and will appeal to both digital samurai and button mashers. However, this is NOT the type of game you play with a keyboard and mouse...GraphicsThey're not the best nor are they the worse - it's a happy medium considering it's a sandbox environment. Load times are near instant on medium systems and there is virtually no FPS choke points that I've encountered despite the hundreds upon hundreds of zombies roaming the city...Overall, this is one of those weekend warrior games that will keep you entertained and decently challenged for a good 30 hours...That’s if you’re going for 100% completion.However, my only complaint is that you can't reach 100% completion without starting a new game on insane mode and racing through the storyline. I bought the DLC thinking that I could finish things up but alas, the EP gains are null. So in other words, buy the dlc for the mini games (which are challenging and fun), but start a 2nd playthrough on insane mode (which inherits everything you've completed in past game modes and only takes a couple of hours) for the extra EP if you want to complete it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												Loved this game. Yes it has a memory leak for pc but dont let that discourage you! The game changes up some things from the first game that didnt work well. One was the minigames; screw those and just have them integrated into the missions. Make enemies easier to consume when they're at low health. Have new game changing abilities, all of which you will use and be encouraged to use. A little more help to get you through the game easier. It might seem like a little much at first but believe me as someone who is a slow learner, it's worthwhile. I loved the perk system and level up system. Unfortunately there isnt a counter for body count anymore or any reason to randomly kill military but you get everything with the second playthrough as long as you do some searching around the city. One suggestion that I wish I knew going into the game: THE MAP HELPS YOU FIND BLACK BOXES, DENS, AND FIELD TEAMS! The general area is pinged on the map if you have something undiscovered. Use this info to your advantage! It can be found under collectibles in the map tabs.My favorite ability is the Bio-Bomb! I literally spent 2 hours alone playing around with it. There is also a RadNet change to it that allows you to kick those you bio-bomb square in the♥♥♥♥♥toward your target! It's fantastic. It allows me to stealth missions easier while removing detectors to move around easier. I used it a lot to stealth kill tanks and helicopters ahead of time for missions. Totally the most useful skill out of combat and can be used for fun in combat as well.Happy hunting!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
												Envigorating Game. Nowhere to hide, always on the run in plain sight of 1000's of civies and 100's of uniformes.Prototype 2 is not a game for the faintharted do-good. And don't expect elaborate dungeons with lots of puzzles, hidden passages and such. Y'can't trust no-one, but hey, a mission is a mission. Prototype 2 is a Hit&Run game. A lot of the time you'll be hitting a bit, get slaughtered a lot and then you need to run for your life and take any available victim to devour for Hitpoint regeneration while on the run. I started the game eating only soldiers, Black Ops, scientists and infected Ppl but i soon realized i should give up that attitude. I had to take my regeneration from inocent civvies. On the streets, in their panic, civvies tend to run toward the fight so there's plenty of food. Also there's a good supply of cars to use as throwing weapons. Once you get the Bio-Bomb ability the fun realy starts, turning Ppl into Bio-Bombs and throwing them at your enemies. Going berserk on a rampage and/or HiJacking a tank in between missions is real good "leasure"time.All in all, this is a fantastic "not completely mindless fighting" game.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												Prototype 2 is a rather exciting game! The characters are awesome,the powers are friggin awesome! (I'm looking at you WhipFist!) everything is awesome in this game! Now,It definitely does not match up to the first game,but that doesn't mean you shouldn't get it! Now there is one problem with the game.....it has severe memory leaks. Incase you don't know what those are,memory leaks cause the game to use up more memory without expelling excess memory. Basically,it lags,FPS goes down ALOT,and it crashes. Not your typical lag,it makes the game unplayable. However,this problem is only on the PC version. If you want the game,get it for the XBox360/PS3! To sum it all up,get the game,but not for PC. It will consume hours of your day!Have fun!

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												Essentially building on the gameplay of the first, Prototype 2 succeeds and fails on roughly the same merits. Fancier black and white cutscenes can't disguise a poor story that trods on the character development of the first, while many of the new methods of unlocking all your slimy, spike-covered evolutions are now tied to list-checking side-missions. The air of requirement on these side missions turns them from a fun diversion in the first to a tedious chore in the second. However, the gameplay itself is, in its way, improved. The list of mutations lost Muscle-Mass but gained the Tendrils, and underachievers like Whip-Fists and Hammerhands gained noticable improvements. Graphical fidelity is improved (but of course, it's the PC port that does it), but it's still roughly more of the same. The change in environments is nice, but in some ways a sour note. In the first game, the ownership of various districts shifted back and forth between military, civilian, and infected ground. Now, the game simply divides into three islands, an infected hellhole, a military lockdown, and a civilian slum. While this does mean that they can sculpt the three types into a much more varied experience, it requires tedious travel between them through abusing either the accidental fast-travel of playing the side-missions from the menu, or running to the few places one can hitch a helicopter from island to island.A game I'd only recommend on sale, but would still recommend.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												Prototype 2 is basically just more of the same. Some game mechanics have been slightly tweaked, but overall it's the same game with a different character.The story is paper thin and aside from the occasional insight into Blackwatch and the science teams fighting the infection, the story might as well not be there at all. Heller, like Mercer in the original game, has absolutely no regard for human life and basically turns into a killing machine the moment the game starts. Except for one situation in the game where he suddenly shows compassion for one single person. His one-liners are enjoyable but as a protagonist he does very little else to wow you.The virus, mutations, upgrades, weapons and shape shifting are the bread and butter of this game. 99% of the time you will be hacking, slashing and impaling Blackwatch soldiers and infected alike with your shape shifting blades and other goodies. As you progress through the game these weapons will become more and more powerful. If you take the time to do side missions this gets to a point where Heller becomes completely overpowered and is able to easily kill anything that gets in his way. Some upgrades even make you immune to small arms fire, making it possible to ignore the majority of the military all together while avoiding rockets.While this kind of power is very fun to play around with, it takes away just about any challenge the game had left to offer. Any enemy that can't be killed in 3 hits can easily be avoided and with a huge surplus of consumeable people around you will never (ever) run out of health. While I played the game on Normal, I can't imagine the game being any more challenging on Hard.It's still a very fun game to play around in. But if you are looking for a solid story or a game that offers a challenge then you best keep searching. This is basically a hack and slash version of GTA and nothing more. Recommended to get when it's on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												This game is awesome. If you're looking for a fun game that let's you feel like the ultimate badass, look no further. The main plot is fun with plot missions having variety in their challenges. The side missions are an absolute joy and this is probably one of the first games where I've ever wanted to get 100% completion because each collectible is fun and easy to look for, but where the game really shines is in how much fun it is to be the main character. Your powers and abilities are just so much freaking fun to use. I regularly eschewed the main quest lines in favor of just running around the city blowing stuff up, and the design of the game with its collectibles, vehicles, random enemies and side missions really encourages you to just have as much fun as possible. After all, isn't that what a video game is for? 10/10 would recommend.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Played for about 30 mins, got to a mission that required me to "pounce attack" an enemy. After retrying this about 10 times, in the final attempt waiting all the way till it seemed that no more, very very slowly appearing "hint text" would appear on screen to tell me how to do this, and still nothing.Apparently, at this point, you must kill this one specific soldier. The interface takes a long time to pop this text up, and the guy you're supposed to kill is standing righ there, in the middle of everything, attacking you with a whole group of others, just after you have a big fight with a monster that gives you a claw attack that instakills everything at this point in the game. So it's very likely you're just going to splat this guy instantly and fail your mission. Apart from that, the opening of the game was very dull and the game just seemed like a dull rehash of the first  Prototype. Play the original instead, I don't remember it being glitchy or slow like this, but fast, fun and fluid.The also felt more sluggish than I remember them being in the original. So no, I did not play this for an extended period or anything, so my recommendation might not mean much, but I can't seriously recommend it when it can't be played past the basic tutorial missions without taking some sort of special care around bugs and problems you probably don't know are there.
